name: Netflix Tech Blog - Experimentation
description: 1000+ engineers, millions of users, zero guesswork. Real case studies on how Netflix actually runs A/B tests at scale.

name: Uber Engineering - Economics
description: Surge pricing, marketplace design, causal inference at scale. See how economists tackle real problems at Uber.

name: Airbnb Engineering - Data Science
description: Experimentation platform design, interference in experiments, and applied causal inference from Airbnb's data science team.

name: Spotify R&D - Machine Learning
description: How do you recommend songs to 500M users? Personalization, search, and ML at audio scale. Serious engineering, not marketing fluff.

name: DoorDash Engineering
description: Marketplace economics, delivery optimization, and experimentation. Great posts on real-time pricing and logistics.

name: Lyft Engineering
description: Rideshare economics, causal inference, and marketplace experiments. Practical posts from Lyft's economics and data science teams.

name: Stitch Fix Algorithms Blog
description: Demand forecasting, inventory optimization, and personalization. Unique blend of fashion retail + serious data science.

name: Causal Inference for the Brave and True
description: The best free intro to causal inference. DiD, IV, RDD, synthetic control — all with Python code you can run. No fluff.

name: The Effect
description: DAGs that don't suck. Nick HK explains causality like he's at a whiteboard, not a lectern. Free, modern, and actually enjoyable to read.

name: Causal Inference: The Mixtape
description: Scott Cunningham's guide — reads like a conversation, not a textbook. Code in Stata, R, and Python.

name: CausalML (Uber) Documentation
description: Synthetic data tutorials that feel like a game. Generate fake users, apply treatment, challenge yourself to recover the effect using Random Forest.

name: EconML Documentation
description: Microsoft's library for ML-based causal inference. Tutorials on heterogeneous treatment effects, double ML, and more.

name: Uber Engineering: Causal Inference
description: How Uber uses synthetic control and causal ML at scale. Real-world applications of methods from 'Brave and True'.

name: DoWhy Library
description: Microsoft's causal inference library. Great for understanding causal graphs and robustness checks.

name: Causal ML Book (Chernozhukov et al.)
description: Applied Causal Inference Powered by ML and AI. Double/debiased ML, heterogeneous effects, and modern methods from the pioneers.

name: Causal Inference (Wager)
description: Stefan Wager's Stanford course notes. Rigorous treatment of causal forests, AIPW, and ML for causal inference.

name: A Practitioner's Guide to DiD
description: Jonathan Roth et al.'s comprehensive guide to modern difference-in-differences. Staggered timing, pre-trends, and new estimators.

name: Eppo's Experimentation Guides
description: Practical guides on experiment design, stats engines, CUPED, and common pitfalls. Written by practitioners.

name: A/B Testing on Social Networks
description: Simulates a social graph in Python to prove why network effects ruin experiments, then shows cluster-based fixes.

name: DoorDash: Switchback Tests
description: Why treating one user affects another in marketplaces. Clear diagrams explaining interference as a living organism, not a static dataset.

name: Nextmv: Switchback Testing
description: Documentation that reads like a tutorial. Exact logic to split time into windows and washout periods for network A/B tests in Python.

name: Matteo Courthoud: Understanding CUPED
description: The closest author to Matheus Facure. Explains CUPED not as statistical theorem, but as simple linear regression adjustment in 3 lines of pandas.

name: Bytepawn: CUPED in Python
description: Short, punchy script simulating 1,000 experiments to prove variance actually goes down. Very satisfying to run.

name: Statsig Resources
description: Deep dives on sequential testing, variance reduction, and experiment analysis. Free stats engine docs.

name: Ronny Kohavi's Experimentation Talks
description: The godfather of online experimentation. His talks distill decades of A/B testing wisdom from Microsoft and Amazon.

name: Evan Miller's A/B Testing Tools
description: Sample size calculators, stats explainers, and practical A/B testing guides. Bookmark-worthy tools.

name: Evan Miller: How Not To Run an A/B Test
description: The article that taught the industry why peeking at p-values is a sin. Short, lethal, career-saving.

name: Sean Taylor: When Do We Need Causal Inference?
description: Former Lyft/Facebook DS lead. This talk saves you from over-engineering. Know when correlation is enough.

name: Andrew Chen: The Cold Start Problem
description: How to bootstrap network effects from zero. The definitive guide to marketplace dynamics — no code, pure systems thinking.

name: QuantEcon Lectures
description: High-quality computational economics in Python and Julia. Dynamic programming, time series, asset pricing — all with code.

name: Coding for Economists
description: Arthur Turrell's practical guide. Python basics through advanced workflows — built specifically for econ researchers.

name: The Missing Semester (MIT)
description: Command line, Git, debugging, shell scripting. The CS skills they don't teach in econ PhD programs but you absolutely need.

name: Python for Econometrics
description: Kevin Sheppard's notes on Python for financial econometrics. NumPy, pandas, statsmodels — the practical toolkit.

name: fast.ai Practical Deep Learning
description: Train a model in 10 minutes. Understand why it works later. Jeremy Howard's famous 'code first, theory second' approach to deep learning.

name: Google ML Crash Course
description: Free, fast intro to ML fundamentals from Google. Great refresher on the basics with TensorFlow examples.

name: Kaggle Learn
description: Bite-sized ML tutorials you can finish in an afternoon. Python, pandas, ML basics, feature engineering.

name: Introduction to Statistical Learning
description: The 'I actually finished this one' ML book. Free with runnable Python code. Math when you need it, intuition first.

name: Forecasting: Principles and Practice
description: Rob Hyndman's free book on time series forecasting. ARIMA, ETS, hierarchical forecasting — with R code.

name: Casual Inference Podcast
description: Lucy D'Agostino McGowan and Ellie Murray make causal inference actually fun to listen to. Like chatting with smart friends.

name: Not So Standard Deviations
description: Roger Peng and Hilary Parker on data science in the real world. Great for understanding the craft.

name: Freakonomics Radio
description: Economics applied to everything. Not technical, but great for economic intuition and communication.

name: Dynamic Pricing with Contextual Bandits
description: Exploration-exploitation trade-off using a restaurant menu example. Simulate greedy vs Thompson Sampling to see which makes more money.

name: Stanford: Thompson Sampling Tutorial
description: Don't let 'Stanford' scare you. The accompanying Python code is the industry standard for bandit algorithms from scratch.

name: Stitch Fix: Algorithms Tour
description: The single best piece of data journalism in tech. Interactive, animated tour of how they combine styles, logistics, and feedback loops.

name: Empirical IO: Coding BLP
description: Matteo Courthoud's code-first walkthrough of the BLP demand model. The 'Brave and True' for structural economics.

name: PyBLP: Demand Estimation
description: QuantEcon tutorial on estimating demand curves with Python. Turns PhD-level IO into a solvable Problem().solve().

name: QuantEcon: First-Price & Second-Price Auctions
description: Python simulations proving Revenue Equivalence. Code to solve BNE when closed-form solutions don't exist.

name: MatchingMarkets.py
description: Gale-Shapley stable matching in Python. How to match riders to drivers, students to schools, organs to patients.

name: Auctions in Ad Tech (Sanjiv Das)
description: GSP auctions, quality scores, AdRank — how Google/Meta ad auctions actually work. Chapter 21.

name: Auction Simulation (Munk-Nielsen)
description: GitHub repo with Python code for simulating and solving auctions. Companion to QuantEcon lectures.

name: Gym-AdServer
description: OpenAI Gym environment for RL in online advertising. Train bidding agents against a simulated ad server.

name: ML for Pricing & Auctions (ICML Tutorial)
description: Design the mechanism, don't just bid in it. RegretNet and deep learning for auction design. The frontier.

name: CS269I: Incentives in Computer Science
description: Roughgarden's famous course. Why Bitcoin is an auction, how selfish routing breaks the internet, and Price of Anarchy — explained for coders.

name: Susan Athey: Causal Forests
description: Leading researcher bridging ML and economics. Essential talks on causal forests and policy evaluation.

name: Hal Varian: Ad Auctions & Platforms
description: Google's Chief Economist on ad auctions, two-sided markets, and how economics shapes tech.

name: Michael Ostrovsky: Marketplace Design
description: Stanford economist on matching markets, auction design, and platform economics.

name: Pat Bajari (Amazon)
description: Amazon's Chief Economist on combining ML with economic models for demand estimation and pricing.

name: Emily Oster
description: Brown economist who makes rigorous analysis accessible. Great for learning how to communicate uncertainty.

name: Dan Garrett: Regression
description: Practical econometrics lectures focused on what actually matters for tech applications. Clean, clear, useful.

name: Tech Econ Job Market Guide
description: How to actually land a tech economist role. Resume tips, interview prep, and what companies look for beyond the PhD.

name: Econ Twitter / X
description: See what tech economists are reading, join the debates. Start with @caaborwn, @nickchk, @gaborcsardi.

name: Data Science Interview Prep
description: Stats, ML, and product sense interviews. Built for the economist-to-tech transition. Ace the Loop knows the pain.
